report_title: Costume & Team Uniform Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: Participation in extracurriculars like theater programs and team sports drives sales for costumes and uniforms, while academic gowns account for another significant share of costume and team uniform manufacturers. These two product segments cater to, at times, the same types of customers but in different ways. Parents' investment in children's theater and sports participation, reflected by costumes and uniform purchases, remains highly discretionary. People must purchase academic gowns for graduation ceremonies, even at elevated prices. A spike in unemployment and canceled children's activities followed the onset of COVID-19, to the detriment of costume and tem uniform manufacturers. 2021's reopening outpaced manufacturing and commodity supply chain realignment, sending prices through the roof as children returned to theater, sports and school.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Costume and team uniform manufacturing is expected to fall
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Costume and team uniform manufacturing is expected to fall at a CAGR of 5.6% to reach $1.1 billion in the next five years, including a 2.2% dip in 2023, when profit reaches 5.7%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Parents Pull Back Spending on Children's Extracurriculars
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Sports and theater participation reflects a parent's time commitment and willingness to spend on costumes, uniforms and gear. 2020 to 2022 exemplify the relationship between parents' investment in children's extracurriculars and macroeconomic factors. COVID-19 canceled most programs and sent unemployment through the roof, while resumed programs and widespread employment in 2021 yielded strong costume and team uniform sales. The resulting inflationary pressure choked parent's wallets and has curbed interest in purchasing costumes and uniforms in 2022 and 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers Struggle to Pass on Input Price Increases
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The price of wool and cotton skyrocketed in 2021 following supply chain disruptions, backlogs and a quick spike in demand. Costume and team uniform manufacturers struggled to meet the new costs, including upward pressure on wages, while maintaining production capacity and profit margins.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Costume and team uniform manufacturing revenue forecast
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Costume and team uniform manufacturing revenue is forecast to fall at a CAGR of 1.0% to reach $1.1 billion over the five years to 2028, including a profit of 5.8%.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The International Market Presents Some Opportunities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Costume and team uniforms will not likely enjoy political support for protectionist policies like in the past five years. The US appears committed to boosting domestic manufacturing but for technology goods related to national security concerns. Costume and team uniforms, like most apparel products, don't fall into that category. Companies will shift to custom and high-quality work to compete with less expensive imports. Cornering premium parts of the domestic market and exporting abroad, including to Mexico, is forecast to drive costume and team uniform manufacturing revenue.

Professional clients will help costume and team uniform manufacturers maintain domestic market share. Companies will seek partnerships with professional sports franchises, leagues, and elite youth leagues. Catering to professional theater companies will yield significant and consistent contracts. Investing in costumes and team uniforms means less focus on academic gowns, previously a prominent segment for manufacturers. High-quality custom caps and gowns worn by professors and academic staff will continue to come from US manufacturers, while the bulk of gowns worn by students must come from abroad.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Companies focus on hiring skilled employees
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The transition to high-quality costumes and team uniforms requires companies to invest in skilled labor, which is abundant in the US. Hiring will slow as companies rely on fewer employees that add more value to the company. Focusing on highly skilled labor comes at a good time, with high interest rates discouraging capital investment but suppressing wages. Depending on skilled labor will save companies money in an environment with climbing capital costs.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures cut and sew apparel (i.e. operators cut and sew purchased fabric into clothing). Products made by this industry include team uniforms, costumes, clerical vestments, and fur and leather apparel. Apparel for men, boys, women, girls and infants is excluded from this industry.
